title: Homework 5
description: For this assignment, you must select at least two variables of interest from your dataset, provide a basic description of the variables, clean and recode as needed, and present descriptive statistics and any visualizations.
contents:
The dataset I will be analyzing is called the “2021-2022 Student Equity Needs Index (SENI) Scores for Elementary Schools,” which shows scores of elementary schools (grades k-5th) in the L.A. Unified School District (LAUSD) in CA. LAUSD is the largest school district in CA and the 2nd largest school district in the U.S. in terms of number of students. “The SENI was implemented to create a more inclusive and holistic understanding of our students’ needs, and to empower schools with additional funds to address those needs at the local level” (Advancement Project, California, 2021) I would like to compare some school demographics. LAUSD consists of 6 local districts, South, East, Central, West, NW, and NE. The dataset shows counts of foster youth, homeless youth, and English learners in each elementary schools. I would like to compare those groups within local districts and find which local district has the highest rates.In the SENI dataset I would like to take a look at 4 variables, the Homeless, Foster, and English Learning Counts. The counts are reported by each elementary school in LAUSD. I would like to compare those numbers by local districts that are within LAUSD.


knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = FALSE)
library(tidyverse)
library(distill)
library(blogbuilder)
library(knitr)
library(ggplot2)






1. Descriptions of the variables - how they were collected, any missing values, etc. The homeless, foster, and English Learner counts are reported by each elementary school in the LAUSD and is recorded in the SENI index. I will take a look at those 3 variables only in each local district and check for missing values.

# A tibble: 6 x 5
  `Local District` `Homeless Count` `Foster Count` `EL Count`
  <chr>                       <dbl>          <dbl>      <dbl>
1 S                              11             16        287
2 S                               5              2        118
3 C                               6              4        238
4 S                               3             11         87
5 S                               1              8         92
6 S                              14              1        100
  `Total Enroll`
           <dbl>
1            833
2            354
3            470
4            350
5            410
6            505


# A tibble: 0 x 5
# ... with 5 variables: Local District <chr>, Homeless Count <dbl>,
#   Foster Count <dbl>, EL Count <dbl>, Total Enroll <dbl>

2. How you cleaned and coded the data, including a before/after comparison as needed. I will recode Local District codes to show full names to make them more distinguishable.

# A tibble: 509 x 5
   `Local District` `Homeless Count` `Foster Count` `EL Count`
   <chr>                       <dbl>          <dbl>      <dbl>
 1 SOUTH                          11             16        287
 2 SOUTH                           5              2        118
 3 CENTRAL                         6              4        238
 4 SOUTH                           3             11         87
 5 SOUTH                           1              8         92
 6 SOUTH                          14              1        100
 7 SOUTH                          13              4        173
 8 SOUTH                          20              4        157
 9 SOUTH                           1              4         94
10 SOUTH                           5              5         32
   `Total Enroll`
            <dbl>
 1            833
 2            354
 3            470
 4            350
 5            410
 6            505
 7            637
 8            612
 9            373
10            374
# ... with 499 more rows

3. Summary descriptives of the recoded variables Creating a pivot table to show summary descriptives.
This grouped it by Local District and gave me a summary of the sums of each count I am interested in.

# A tibble: 6 x 5
  `Local District` Total_Homeless Total_Foster Total_EL Total_Enroll
  <chr>                     <dbl>        <dbl>    <dbl>        <dbl>
1 SOUTH                       425          486    10477        44228
2 CENTRAL                     387          293    12732        39429
3 NORTHWEST                   336          203     7209        38714
4 WEST                        273          299     7076        38174
5 EAST                        164          317    10028        37090
6 NORTHEAST                   277          271     8489        33229

Taking a look at percentages by total students enrolled. If we look at percentages, ranking changes. Central local district has the highest rate of homeless students.

# A tibble: 6 x 4
  `Local District` Total_Homeless Total_Enroll Homeless_Rate
  <chr>                     <dbl>        <dbl>         <dbl>
1 CENTRAL                     387        39429       0.00982
2 SOUTH                       425        44228       0.00961
3 NORTHWEST                   336        38714       0.00868
4 NORTHEAST                   277        33229       0.00834
5 WEST                        273        38174       0.00715
6 EAST                        164        37090       0.00442

Based on total students enrolled, the South local district still has the highest rate of foster children.

# A tibble: 6 x 4
  `Local District` Total_Foster Total_Enroll Foster_Rate
  <chr>                   <dbl>        <dbl>       <dbl>
1 SOUTH                     486        44228     0.0110 
2 EAST                      317        37090     0.00855
3 NORTHEAST                 271        33229     0.00816
4 WEST                      299        38174     0.00783
5 CENTRAL                   293        39429     0.00743
6 NORTHWEST                 203        38714     0.00524

Based on total students enrolled, the Central local district has the highest rate of English learning students.

# A tibble: 6 x 4
  `Local District` Total_EL Total_Enroll EL_Rate
  <chr>               <dbl>        <dbl>   <dbl>
1 CENTRAL             12732        39429   0.323
2 EAST                10028        37090   0.270
3 NORTHEAST            8489        33229   0.255
4 SOUTH               10477        44228   0.237
5 NORTHWEST            7209        38714   0.186
6 WEST                 7076        38174   0.185

4. Description of the relationship between the variables, including a hypothesis (or hypotheses) about the relationship.
With the pivot table above I can see that the South local district has the most homeless and foster students and Central local district has the most English Learning students. Based on total students enrolled in each local district, the Central local district has the highest rates of homeless and English learning students and the South local district has the highest rate of foster children. We can take a look at the relationship between these rates and their location. According to the Los Angeles Area Chamber of Commerce, neighborhoods of concentrated poverty are clustered throughout South Los Angeles and Downtown adjacent areas, which is where the South and Central local districts are located. A hypothesis here can be that the highest level of homeless students are most likely to attend schools in the South Local District, making a correlation between location and homeless students and maybe English learning students.**
5. Initial demonstration of the relationship, which could include correlation, visualization, or statistical model. Appropriate visualizations.
A bar/column chart clearly shows which of the local districts have the highest rates of each group of interest. Highlighting the value or observation you want to draw focus on helps get the message across. This could help if maybe I am trying to get a key stakeholder to allocate funding or provide certain resources to a local district in need.

title: Homework 4
description:
For this assignment, you will be creating and explaining a data visualization.
  Your goal is to build on the previous assignments, and create a data visualization using the dataset you have been working with in R. Then, use R Markdown to draft a document that tracks the creation of the data visualization. In particular, comment on and discuss:
  1. What the visualization demonstrates.
  2. Why you chose the visualization approach you selected, and what alternative approaches you considered but decided not to pursue.
  3. What you wished, if anything, you could have executed but found limited capability to do.
contents:
#Importing dataset
library(readxl)
SENISData <- read_excel("../../_data/SENIScoresElementaryShools-20212022.xlsx")





#Creating tidySENI to only show variables of interest.
tidySENI <- select(SENISData, c('Local District', 
                                'Homeless Count', 
                                'Foster Count', 
                                'EL Count', 
                                'Total Enroll'))
tidySENI


# A tibble: 509 x 5
   `Local District` `Homeless Count` `Foster Count` `EL Count`
   <chr>                       <dbl>          <dbl>      <dbl>
 1 S                              11             16        287
 2 S                               5              2        118
 3 C                               6              4        238
 4 S                               3             11         87
 5 S                               1              8         92
 6 S                              14              1        100
 7 S                              13              4        173
 8 S                              20              4        157
 9 S                               1              4         94
10 S                               5              5         32
   `Total Enroll`
            <dbl>
 1            833
 2            354
 3            470
 4            350
 5            410
 6            505
 7            637
 8            612
 9            373
10            374
# ... with 499 more rows



#Re-coded Local District values to make them easier to read
tidySENI[,1] <- ifelse(tidySENI[,1]== "S", "SOUTH", 
                       ifelse(tidySENI[,1]== "C", "CENTRAL", 
                              ifelse(tidySENI[,1]=="W", "WEST", 
                                     ifelse(tidySENI[,1]=="E", "EAST", 
                                            ifelse(tidySENI[,1]=="NE", "NORTHEAST", 
                                                   ifelse(tidySENI[,1]=="NW", "NORTHWEST", 
                                                          99 ))))))
tidySENI


# A tibble: 509 x 5
   `Local District` `Homeless Count` `Foster Count` `EL Count`
   <chr>                       <dbl>          <dbl>      <dbl>
 1 SOUTH                          11             16        287
 2 SOUTH                           5              2        118
 3 CENTRAL                         6              4        238
 4 SOUTH                           3             11         87
 5 SOUTH                           1              8         92
 6 SOUTH                          14              1        100
 7 SOUTH                          13              4        173
 8 SOUTH                          20              4        157
 9 SOUTH                           1              4         94
10 SOUTH                           5              5         32
   `Total Enroll`
            <dbl>
 1            833
 2            354
 3            470
 4            350
 5            410
 6            505
 7            637
 8            612
 9            373
10            374
# ... with 499 more rows

Playing with pivot_longer, didn’t help


pivlongSENI <-  tidySENI %>%
  pivot_longer(c(`Homeless Count`, `Foster Count`, `EL Count`), 
               names_to = "Counts", values_to = "Cases")
pivlongSENI


# A tibble: 1,527 x 4
   `Local District` `Total Enroll` Counts         Cases
   <chr>                     <dbl> <chr>          <dbl>
 1 SOUTH                       833 Homeless Count    11
 2 SOUTH                       833 Foster Count      16
 3 SOUTH                       833 EL Count         287
 4 SOUTH                       354 Homeless Count     5
 5 SOUTH                       354 Foster Count       2
 6 SOUTH                       354 EL Count         118
 7 CENTRAL                     470 Homeless Count     6
 8 CENTRAL                     470 Foster Count       4
 9 CENTRAL                     470 EL Count         238
10 SOUTH                       350 Homeless Count     3
# ... with 1,517 more rows

Playing with pivot wider but didn’t help much either.


pivwideSENI <-  tidySENI %>% 
  pivot_wider(names_from = `Local District`, values_from = `Homeless Count`)
pivwideSENI


# A tibble: 509 x 9
   `Foster Count` `EL Count` `Total Enroll` SOUTH CENTRAL  EAST  WEST
            <dbl>      <dbl>          <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
 1             16        287            833    11      NA    NA    NA
 2              2        118            354     5      NA    NA    NA
 3              4        238            470    NA       6    NA    NA
 4             11         87            350     3      NA    NA    NA
 5              8         92            410     1      NA    NA    NA
 6              1        100            505    14      NA    NA    NA
 7              4        173            637    13      NA    NA    NA
 8              4        157            612    20      NA    NA    NA
 9              4         94            373     1      NA    NA    NA
10              5         32            374     5      NA    NA    NA
   NORTHWEST NORTHEAST
       <dbl>     <dbl>
 1        NA        NA
 2        NA        NA
 3        NA        NA
 4        NA        NA
 5        NA        NA
 6        NA        NA
 7        NA        NA
 8        NA        NA
 9        NA        NA
10        NA        NA
# ... with 499 more rows



tidySENI %>% 
  filter(`Local District` == 'S')


# A tibble: 0 x 5
# ... with 5 variables: Local District <chr>, Homeless Count <dbl>,
#   Foster Count <dbl>, EL Count <dbl>, Total Enroll <dbl>

I’m excited I finally got to figure out how to create a pivot table that is grouped by Local District and I can see the sums of each count! I can see now that the Local District with the most Homeless and foster children is the South, which has the highest enrollment. I would now like to check for percentages by total enrollment. After that I will 


#Grouping by Local District and showing sums of each Count within Local Districts 
  #and arranging by Total Enroll in descending order. Like a pivot table ! Yay!  
seni_total <- tidySENI %>% 
  group_by(`Local District`) %>% 
  summarise(
    Total_Homeless=sum(`Homeless Count`), 
    Total_Foster=sum(`Foster Count`), 
    Total_EL=sum(`EL Count`),
    Total_Enroll=sum(`Total Enroll`)) %>% 
  arrange(desc(`Total_Enroll`))
seni_total


# A tibble: 6 x 5
  `Local District` Total_Homeless Total_Foster Total_EL Total_Enroll
  <chr>                     <dbl>        <dbl>    <dbl>        <dbl>
1 SOUTH                       425          486    10477        44228
2 CENTRAL                     387          293    12732        39429
3 NORTHWEST                   336          203     7209        38714
4 WEST                        273          299     7076        38174
5 EAST                        164          317    10028        37090
6 NORTHEAST                   277          271     8489        33229

I want to focus on variable seperately now. To look at only the homeless count I created a tibble called seni_homeless by selecting local districts, total homeless and total enroll and also added a new variable to calculate percentage of total homeless of total enroll titles “homeless percentage”.


#Checking percentage of total homeless in each local district based on the total enrolled
#Added new variable showing homeless percentage
seni_homeless <- seni_total %>% select('Local District','Total_Homeless', 'Total_Enroll') %>% 
  mutate("Homeless_Percentage"=Total_Homeless/Total_Enroll)
seni_homeless


# A tibble: 6 x 4
  `Local District` Total_Homeless Total_Enroll Homeless_Percentage
  <chr>                     <dbl>        <dbl>               <dbl>
1 SOUTH                       425        44228             0.00961
2 CENTRAL                     387        39429             0.00982
3 NORTHWEST                   336        38714             0.00868
4 WEST                        273        38174             0.00715
5 EAST                        164        37090             0.00442
6 NORTHEAST                   277        33229             0.00834

By using a bar chart, with Local District and sums of Total homeless, we can clearly see which local district has the highest count. I want to try and arrange totals by descending order to see largest to least. I think a bar chart for each Count can be a good way to go to show numbers.


#Creating a bar graph to show homeless count in each local district. 
#Note to self: Remember to use back ticks `` on variable names for it to work!
library(ggplot2)
gg_homeless <- ggplot(data=seni_homeless, aes(x=`Local District`, y=`Total_Homeless`)) +
         geom_bar(stat="identity")
gg_homeless




Other visuals to consider using is a different column graph showing all the variables of interest and setting them as different colors and leaving local districts on the y axis. But I still think separating them to small multiples would be better. Stacked bars can get confusing. It would be cool if I can create the map of the local districts and show density of populations with colors, for example, the south local district will have the darkest shade and the east will have the lightest shade. That sounds like it could be a lot to figure out to do in R but I can look into it.

title: Homework 3
description: For this assignment, you must select at least two variables of interest from your dataset, provide a basic description of the variables, clean and recode as needed, and present descriptive statistics and any visualizations.
contents:
Homework 3


#Importing dataset
library(readxl)
SENISData <- read_excel("../../_data/SENIScoresElementaryShools-20212022.xlsx")



In the SENI dataset I would like to take a look at 4 variables, the Homeless, Foster, and English Learning Counts. The counts are reported by each elementary school in LAUSD. I would like to compare those numbers by local districts that are within the LA Unified School District.
First I want to create a tibble showing only the columns or variables I want to focus on, Local districts, homeless, foster, EL count and total enrolled. 


#Selecting the variables I will be evaluating and renaming that to tidySENI.
tidySENI <- select(SENISData, c('Local District', 'Homeless Count', 'Foster Count', 'EL Count', 'Total Enroll'))
tidySENI


# A tibble: 509 x 5
   `Local District` `Homeless Count` `Foster Count` `EL Count`
   <chr>                       <dbl>          <dbl>      <dbl>
 1 S                              11             16        287
 2 S                               5              2        118
 3 C                               6              4        238
 4 S                               3             11         87
 5 S                               1              8         92
 6 S                              14              1        100
 7 S                              13              4        173
 8 S                              20              4        157
 9 S                               1              4         94
10 S                               5              5         32
   `Total Enroll`
            <dbl>
 1            833
 2            354
 3            470
 4            350
 5            410
 6            505
 7            637
 8            612
 9            373
10            374
# ... with 499 more rows

Checked the variables of interest for missing values and none were found. Good to go.


#Checking for missing values in new tidySENI dataset
tidySENI[!complete.cases(tidySENI),]


# A tibble: 0 x 5
# ... with 5 variables: Local District <chr>, Homeless Count <dbl>,
#   Foster Count <dbl>, EL Count <dbl>, Total Enroll <dbl>

Found that there are 6 local districts in LAUSD; South, Central, East, West, Northwest, and Northeast.


#Checking how many local districts there are and their labels
pivot_wider(tidySENI, 'Local District')


# A tibble: 6 x 1
  `Local District`
  <chr>           
1 S               
2 C               
3 E               
4 W               
5 NW              
6 NE              

Map of LAUSD local districts 

#Re-coded Local District values to make them easier to read
tidySENI[,1] <- ifelse(tidySENI[,1]== "S", "SOUTH", ifelse(tidySENI[,1]== "C", "CENTRAL", ifelse(tidySENI[,1]=="W", "WEST", ifelse(tidySENI[,1]=="E", "EAST", ifelse(tidySENI[,1]=="NE", "NORTHEAST", ifelse(tidySENI[,1]=="NW", "NORTHWEST", 99 ))))))
tidySENI


# A tibble: 509 x 5
   `Local District` `Homeless Count` `Foster Count` `EL Count`
   <chr>                       <dbl>          <dbl>      <dbl>
 1 SOUTH                          11             16        287
 2 SOUTH                           5              2        118
 3 CENTRAL                         6              4        238
 4 SOUTH                           3             11         87
 5 SOUTH                           1              8         92
 6 SOUTH                          14              1        100
 7 SOUTH                          13              4        173
 8 SOUTH                          20              4        157
 9 SOUTH                           1              4         94
10 SOUTH                           5              5         32
   `Total Enroll`
            <dbl>
 1            833
 2            354
 3            470
 4            350
 5            410
 6            505
 7            637
 8            612
 9            373
10            374
# ... with 499 more rows

Viewing summary of the tidySENI set I can see the mean/average, minimum and maximum amount of each of the variable counts. So the maximum homeless count is 50 and average is 3.6 or 4, the maximum count of foster is 19 and average is 3.6 or 4 and the max of English Learning counts is 410 and the average is 110. 


summary(tidySENI)


 Local District     Homeless Count   Foster Count      EL Count  
 Length:509         Min.   : 0.00   Min.   : 0.00   Min.   :  2  
 Class :character   1st Qu.: 0.00   1st Qu.: 1.00   1st Qu.: 37  
 Mode  :character   Median : 2.00   Median : 3.00   Median : 94  
                    Mean   : 3.66   Mean   : 3.67   Mean   :110  
                    3rd Qu.: 5.00   3rd Qu.: 6.00   3rd Qu.:165  
                    Max.   :50.00   Max.   :19.00   Max.   :410  
  Total Enroll 
 Min.   :  74  
 1st Qu.: 319  
 Median : 434  
 Mean   : 454  
 3rd Qu.: 570  
 Max.   :1251  



# Viewing how many schools are in each local district
table(tidySENI$`Local District`) 



  CENTRAL      EAST NORTHEAST NORTHWEST     SOUTH      WEST 
       93        85        67        81        85        98 

My next goal on this data is to find a way to combine numbers for each local district. For example if I were to analyse in Excel I can create a pivot table showing how many Homeless, Foster, and English Learners are in each local district and summarize by sum and percentages. Then create a visual to demonstrate findings.

title: HW 2
description: Discussing dataset I am working on
contents:
Homework 2
The dataset I will be analyzing is called the “2021-2022 Student Equity Needs Index (SENI) Scores for Elementary Schools,” which shows scores of elementary schools (grades k-5th) in the L.A. Unified School District (LAUSD) in CA. LAUSD is the largest school district in CA and the 2nd largest school district in the U.S. in terms of number of students. “The SENI was implemented to create a more inclusive and holistic understanding of our students’ needs, and to empower schools with additional funds to address those needs at the local level.” I’m going to try and compare some school demographics. LAUSD consits of 6 local districts, South, East, Central, West, NW, and NE. The dataset shows percent of foster youth, homeless youth, and English learners in elementary schools. I would like to compare those groups within local districts and find which local district has the highest rates.
Imported dataset.


#Importing data
library(readxl)
SENISData <- read_excel("../../_data/SENIScoresElementaryShools-20212022.xlsx")



Checked dimension of dataset. Dataset has 509 rows/observations and 45 columns/variables


dim(SENISData)


[1] 509  45

Checking if there are any missing values


sum(is.na(SENISData))


[1] 15

Checking where those 15 NA’s are


colSums(is.na(SENISData))


                           School Year 
                                     0 
                           School Name 
                                     0 
                      Cost Center Code 
                                     0 
                                 Index 
                                     0 
                           School Type 
                                     0 
                        Board District 
                                     0 
                        Local District 
                                     0 
                             Locn Code 
                                     0 
                              CDS Code 
                                     0 
                          Total Enroll 
                                     0 
                          Foster Count 
                                     0 
                           Foster Rate 
                                     0 
                           Foster Rank 
                                     0 
                        Homeless Count 
                                     0 
                         Homeless Rate 
                                     0 
                         Homeless Rank 
                                     0 
                              EL Count 
                                     0 
                               EL Rate 
                                     0 
                               EL Rank 
                                     0 
                             SEL Count 
                                     6 
                              SEL Rate 
                                     0 
                              SEL Rank 
                                     0 
                    Unduplicated Count 
                                     0 
                     Unduplicated Rate 
                                     0 
                     Unduplicated Rank 
                                     0 
                             Susp Rate 
                                     0 
                        Susp Rate Rank 
                                     0 
                     Dibels Gr1 BM BOY 
                                     0 
                      DIBELS Gr 1 Rank 
                                     0 
                          Chronic Rate 
                                     0 
                      Chronic Abs Rank 
                                     0 
                          LI-SWD Count 
                                     0 
                           LI-SWD Rate 
                                     0 
                           LI-SWD Rank 
                                     0 
                         ISTAR 2016-17 
                                     3 
                         ISTAR 2017-18 
                                     3 
                         ISTAR 2018-19 
                                     3 
                         ISTAR 3Yr Avg 
                                     0 
                            ISTAR Rank 
                                     0 
              Asthma Age Adjusted Rate 
                                     0 
                  Asthma Severity Rank 
                                     0 
        Non-Fatal Gunshot Injury Count 
                                     0 
         Non-Fatal Gunshot Injury Rank 
                                     0 
                    Seni Score 2020-21 
                                     0 
Seni Rank for the 2021-2022 Allocation 
                                     0 

Found that there are NO missing values in the variables I will be analyzing. Checking number of schools in each Local District


table(select(SENISData, "Local District"))



 C  E NE NW  S  W 
93 85 67 81 85 98 

Found there are more schools in West local district. Found 93 schools in Central district, 85 schools in East district, 67 in NE district, 85 in South District, and 98 in West district.
Reviewing average rates of Foster, Homeless, and English Learner rates in all of school district.


summarise(SENISData, mean(`Homeless Rate`))


# A tibble: 1 x 1
  `mean(\`Homeless Rate\`)`
                      <dbl>
1                   0.00870



summarise(SENISData, mean(`Foster Rate`))


# A tibble: 1 x 1
  `mean(\`Foster Rate\`)`
                    <dbl>
1                 0.00860



summarise(SENISData, mean(`EL Rate`))


# A tibble: 1 x 1
  `mean(\`EL Rate\`)`
                <dbl>
1               0.237

Average rates within variables are low based on the means found, less than 25%. Homeless Rate mean is 0.9% , Foster Rate mean is 0.9%, and English Learner Rate mean is 24%.
